dspace-development.title: Restore the Senior Theses Collections in the staging environment

comments.body: It was determined that I should attempt to restore two departments within the staging environment, and look to script a mechanism for restoring ARKs for these Items.
https://github.com/jrgriffiniii/dspace-postgresql-utils/commit/fe9c2b1d7d472157d5a8e2137f4e3b335f7ec786 implements a reporting task for the ARKs in the stable database snapshot.

https://github.com/jrgriffiniii/dspace-postgresql-utils/commit/8d69f98e75fecabddbf97a3ce0f786a91f9a99b6 and https://github.com/jrgriffiniii/dspace-postgresql-utils/commit/465c29c5b02bfed19b46ff57f364376effdbc0b5 have the handles updated from this report.

The following need to be exported from Thesis Central:

- [x] Religion
- [x] Music
- [x] Creative Writing Program
- [x] Woodrow Wilson School
- [x] Spanish and Portuguese
- [x] Sociology
- [x] Slavic Languages and Literatures
- [x] Psychology
- [x] Ops Research and Financial Engineering
- [x] Near Eastern Studies
- [x] Molecular Biology
- [x] Independent Study
- [ ] History
- [ ] German
- [ ] French and Italian
- [ ] Electrical Engineering
- [ ] Economics
- [ ] Ecology and Environmental Biology
- [ ] East Asian Studies
- [ ] Computer Science
- [ ] Comparative Literature
- [ ] Classics
- [ ] Civil and Environmental Engineering
- [ ] Architecture
- [ ] Anthropology
- [ ] African American Studies
I will need to test adding users to the task pool for this, and should start with testing for kl-- [at] princeton.edu.

figgy.title: Add a date facet to Figgy

comments.body:
date_created is a string field which according to our tests expects to handle values such as "circa 1865" and "1941-1985".

In order to facet these will need to be normalized into year-only dates. In order to use blacklight-range-limit they will need to be sortable, integer values.

Orangelight uses blacklight-range-limit by pulling the start date from the 008 ([logic here](https://github.com/pulibrary/marc_liberation/blob/493949186cbb8cf5f6bb888aced888cfca149051/marc_to_solr/lib/princeton_marc.rb#L59-L66)) And in Figgy that is the same logic used to populated "date created" (logic [here](https://github.com/pulibrary/figgy/blob/3c3283c47c3154398b55ddb83e7f025060686fef/app/services/pul_metadata_services/bib_record.rb#L19) and [here](https://github.com/pulibrary/figgy/blob/3c3283c47c3154398b55ddb83e7f025060686fef/app/services/pul_metadata_services/bib_record.rb#L86-L88)).

For finding aid items, figgy pulls the display date into the `date_created` field but we pull a normalized iso8601 date into the `created` field. It would be preferable to use this normalized value as the source for the facet.

Implementation proposal:

1. Create a new Valkyrie field on ScannedResource called `pub_date_start_sort` (this is what it's called in orangelilght) to use as the facet field. Then:
   1. Either pull the value during metadata synchronization.
   1. Or at index time check the source metadata identifier. if it's a bib number copy the `date_created` field into the new facet field. If it's a component ID extract the year from the `created` field.

@hackmastera I don't think we actually use `PulMetadataServices::BibRecord` and haven't in a long time. I think we just pull the data from the JSON-LD serialization here: https://bibdata.princeton.edu/bibliographic/5317891/jsonld. That being said, `created` is definitely right. We pull it here: https://github.com/pulibrary/marc_liberation/blob/493949186cbb8cf5f6bb888aced888cfca149051/app/models/jsonld_record.rb#L56-L67 and https://github.com/pulibrary/marc_liberation/blob/master/app/models/jsonld_record.rb#L24

Is there any reason we can't just add an indexer that adds what's in the `created` field to the index?

Well, look forward to a refactor ticket.

Then it sounds like we can expect created to always have a value we can use here.

Option `ii` above then becomes what you've just said -- an indexer that pulls the `created` value.
We might have to separate the start/end dates into two fields, right now it combines them if it can, but maybe we can just do that at index time.
We'll plan to just pull the start date, as is done in orangelight.

princeton_ansible.title: we are granting the dspace user apache2 rights

comments.body:
schematron (https://rubygems.org/gems/schematron)
running into installation issues: `error occurred while installing libxml-ruby (1.1.4), and Bundler cannot continue`

schematron-nokogiri (https://github.com/alexxed/schematron)
(same co-author; this one relies on Nokogiri)
requires schematron but "cannot load such file"

If we can get one of these to work, we could rewrite the local schema entirely in schematron IF we need the interleave rules that Nokogiri::XML::RelaxNG skips.

Make Homepage Hours pull from libcal

comments.body:
JSON for Today's hours for each location:

For Special Collections: https://libcal.princeton.edu/api_hours_today.php?iid=771&lid=14275&format=json&systemTime=1
For Mudd: https://libcal.princeton.edu/api_hours_today.php?iid=771&lid=12315&format=json&systemTime=1
All locations: https://libcal.princeton.edu/api_hours_today.php?iid=771&lid=0&format=json&systemTime=1

There is also a more fully featured REST-style API that requires the passing of an access token. Let me know if that route seems preferable over. 

https://ask.springshare.com/libcal/faq/1407
